Ha, what sad object's this? How camest thou wounded?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Sure some sheep has bit him.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Speak how camest thou hurt?

sp.speaker: Shepherdess
sp.l: In rescue of our Queen, basely surprised.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Surprised? by whom?

sp.speaker: Shepherdess
sp.p: By Thrace his King, who pilgrim-like wrapped in a russet weed, taking advantage when she was alone, has with a private ambush, stole her hence.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: To the court-gates let us pursue the ravisher, his court and all the powers that he can raise, shall not protect him. Plague upon his craft: is this his skill in physiognomy? Worthy friend, let me but call you so, and let our strife be buried in our loves: the cause removed, let the effect thus die: and as our hands, so let our hearts unite to take revenge on this injurious King.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Sir, what is yet scarce man, my heart shall ripen,
I'll stretch beyond my years and power of strength,
But I'll assist you in this enterprise:

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Let's muster all the shepherds to our aid,
And fetch her back per force.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: In the mean time, be it your charge to cure this
Wounded swain, that sought to rescue her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I'll use my best of skill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Old as I am,
I'll go along, and let my mistress know,
The King of Thrace makes Antimon his foe.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: If I light on him handsomely, I'll have a bout with him at quarterstaff.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: One thing let me entreat, to draw my frantic brother to the field, inform him 'tis Serena is stolen hence, to prove if either terror of the wars, his mistress loss, or sight of death and blood, can win him to his wits.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Persuaded well.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: What's he will take that charge?
Marry that will I, let me alone with him,
I'll put it in his pate, I cannot say his brains,
Because he has none: I'll fetch him presently.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: Whom shall we make our general, and leader of this rabble?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: Who but yourself shall we impose so great a charge upon?

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Rather bestow it on this noble youth.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: That warlike charge would not become my years,
I shall be proud to be your soldier, sir.

div.stage: Enter Pallemon and clown.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Give me my arms, I'll fetch her back again.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Give you more legs, you'll never o'ertake her else.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I'll leap into the saddle of the moon,
And tie two stars unto my heels, like spurs;
I'll make my warlike lance of a sunbeam,
And mounted on some strange Bucephalus,
Thus will I overthrow my enemy.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: This 'tis to keep madmen company, that has not the wit to know his friends from his foes; but we shall have your brains beat in again.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Sirrah, take the moon, and place it me upon the axletree, I'll mount on horseback straight.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: The moon's not up yet, sir, some three hours hence you shall be sure to have her.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: How know you that, sir?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Well enough sir, 'tis a shepherd that keeps her,
and he's called the man in the moon.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I'll fetch a sheepskin then to make a drum,
Ta, ra, ranta, ra, tan, tara, ran tan.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: He has possessed him well, let him go on.
Now courage, fellow-soldiers, and let's try
To fetch her back, or in her quarrel die.

div.stage: Tromp. Flor. enter Pheander, lords, drums, colours, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Is't possible the number of the swains
Should be so many?

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: Full five hundred strong.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: What's their pretence?

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.p: That's yet unknown, my lord, unless it be to have their Queen again.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: How should they know 'twas we that stole her thence?

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.p: Belike the swains that sought to rescue her, heard some one name the King; no other cause could give intelligence, 'twas done so private.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: What should we fear? Let's meet 'em in the field,
Were their force trebled o'er, when we appear
They'll fly like hares that fear the lions frowns.
How might we do for to behold the rebels?

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.p: They lie so low entrenched beyond the hill that fronts the castle-gate, that no prospect about the house can yield the least survey.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Let's parley with 'em then, so we may hear what they pretend, and view their regiment.

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: Here is a herald to the same effect arrived at court.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Go, bring him in, we'll hear what brave defiance they have sent.
sp.stage: Enter old Antimon with a piece of painted cloth, like a herald's coat, clown sounding a tucket before him.
sp.l: Now sir, the prologue to this bloody tragedy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am a herald, come to tell the King,
That he has done a most mischievous thing:
We had but one fair ewe amongst our lambs,
And he has stolen her, with his wolvish rams;
For which our shepherds vow by force of arms,
to fetch her back, kill all, but do no harm:
But if you'll set her free, they bid me say,
They'll take her home, and so make holiday.

sp.speaker: Omnes lords.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It seems they are not angry at my words, because they laugh, I feared they'd draw their swords.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Tell 'em we render thanks for their good mirth,
And would entreat a parley, if they'll come
And meet us here under the castlewall.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You would entreat 'em fairly for to come?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I thought as much. Go you along with him, and tell their general what you heard us say.

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: I shall. Come, show me to your general.

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: Will you in person parley with the rout?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Why not?

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: 'Tis dangerous, for fear the swains,
Not knowing what belongs to law of arms,
Being once crossed, should offer violence.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: 'Tis well advised: Pastatio bid our guard
Be near our person, bring up all our troops
Close to the gates, that if occasion serve,
They may at unawares make issue forth,
And cut off all the reár. See it performed,
I have a trick new crept into my brain,
And if my policy deceive me not,

sp.speaker: A march within.
sp.l: Shall bring these several bodies to one head,
And crown all my designs with full event.
They're coming, keep your ranks.

div.stage: Enter all the shepherds, Radagon, Eusanius, Titterus, Pallemon, clown, Antimon.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Which is the general?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: This.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: We would exchange some private words with him.

sp.speaker: Radag.
sp.l: You are deceived; I better understand
The name and honour of a general,
Than to disgrace it 'gainst the law of arms;
Though we are not so expert as those men
That daily practice 'em, yet you shall find
We'll make a shift to right our injuries.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Is death! where learned he this discipline?
Are shepherds now become such martialists?
I see I must dissemble.

sp.speaker: Radag.
sp.l: If you have ought to say, speak publickly
No private protestations, bribes, nor fears,
Have power to convert our resolutions.
We need not to capitulate our wrongs,
They are too apparent. Let us see our Queen,
And if she have received the smallest wrong,
A general ruin shall o'erspread the land;
We'll fire thy castles, burn up all thy towns,
And make a desolation of thy people:

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You cannot be so shallow, as to think I took her with a lustful appetite? This honoured badge proclaims that lust is past. Our seizing her was motive to your good, if you conceive it. List, and I'll explain it: within our land our foes are resident, Scicilla's King, under whose government these many years you have been servitors. The reason this: when he did first invade, we found ourselves too weak to make resistance, and under show of satisfaction we did resign to him our dignity, pretending search of Radagon his son; which he accepted, and did back return to Sicilia, leaving deputy to govern here. And though Pallatio bore the name of rule, it was by his permission. Do but weigh the servile yoke of foreign government, what danger may ensue, what privilege you lose in Thrace, if we be dispossessed, the time of truce expired, and he's returned to take possession? For without his son, our crown and kingdom both are forfeited into his hands; which yet we may prevent, if you'll agree to join your force with ours, and back expulse him. We'll not only grant your Queen her liberty, but we'll enlarge your former privilege; give you choice of state, honour, and dignity, make you lords and knights, and in remembrance of the shepherd's wars, add a new festival; which at your charge shall yearly be performed. Consider on't.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Happy position! thanks great justicer,
Occasion puts revenge into my hand,
To think that I should be so fortunate,
to be commander of a band of men,
To war against my father, blessed event.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: What's your reply?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Good general, consent,
I have a foolish desire to be a lord.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And what shall I be?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: You shall be a lord too, and if you'll be quiet,
There are a great many mad lords.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: What answer do you give?

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Were it in me
To give an answer, you should soon prevail,
But 'tis a general voice; for my own part
My service, and myself I offer to you.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: So do we all.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: A King that's thus held up can never fall.
Draw all your force within the castle walls,
'Tis large and spacious, and will well contain 'em.
This night we'll feast, tomorrow shall be seen
Your loves to us.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Ours to the shepherd's Queen.

div.head: Act. 5. Scene. 1.
div.stage: Drum and colours.
Enter Scicillia, lords, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: Is all our army in a readiness,
Prepared for battle if occasion serve?

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: They are, my lord.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: This day our truce takes end, the King returned,
And we expect our son's delivery.

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: Pray heaven it be so happy, but I fear
A worse intent, for all the way he comes
The commons rise, shepherds and silly swains
That never were enured to carry swords,
take arms and follow him.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: What's that to us?
Did he not make a vow never to return,
Until he found my son? may be he comes
For to invest us King, and offer sacrifice
Unto the gods, and so conclude this weary pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: You speak, my liege, as you yourself would do,
But he that dared to banish 'em,
Think you he fears to violate an oath?
'Tis ill to trust a reconciled foe,
Be still in readiness, you do not know
How soon he may assault us.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: Thou speakest but well, 'tis good to doubt the worst,
We may in our belief be too secure;
As King's forbidden to condemn the just,
So Kings for safety must not blame mistrust.

sp.speaker: Enter 2 lord.
sp.l: Why is this haste?
To bid you haste to arms,
The foe comes on, the sentinels fall off,
The scouts are posting up and down the plain,
To fetch in all the stragglers. Thrace's King
Has break his vow, and seeks by force of arms
For to expulse you.

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: Will ye yet give credit
To a tyrant's oath?

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: By you bright sphere I vow, and if there be
A greater punishment for perjury
Reigning on earth, then is the conscience sting,
I will inflict it on this perjured man.
You spirits resolute 'gainst fear and death,
You that have hither to maintained your being
In equal power, like rivals to the gods,
Now show your valour, let us not debate
Our wrongs like women; for the wrath of Kings
Is like an angry cloud, swollen big with fire,
Soft charge. that speaks revenge in thunder; hark they charge.
Beat a defiance see, the signal's given,
Who dies in this just cause, shall live in heaven.

sp.speaker: Allarum.
sp.p: The shepherds give the first assault, and beat off some of the Sicilian lords.

div.stage: Enter Eusanius driving over Scicilla. Enter Radagon.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: The fury of this boy will overthrow
All my designs; twice since the fight begun,
In spite of my best art, he has unhorsed
My royal father, and the last career
Drew blood from his shrunk veins, yet the good old man,
Like to an aged oak that long hath stood,
Endangers all that seeks to cut him down;
He does not bear that fearful policy,
That many use to fight in base disguise,
But has a white flag carried before him,
Which does signify the justice of his cause, is innocence;
Or as a mark, as if a man should say,
I am the butt you aim at, shoot at me.
The greatest conquest I have won this day,
Hath been the preservation of his life,
With hazard of mine own: in my pursuit,
Thinking to place him in his court of guard,
I followed him so far, that I was forced
To make retire, for to recover breath.

div.stage: Enter Eusanius with Scicillia prisoner.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Why do you sound a retreat? the day is ours,
See, here's their King, I knew him by his ensign,
Which I seized in spite of all opposed.
Here general, to your hands I do commit him.
Carry Thrace's King this as a ransom for the shepherd's Queen.

sp.speaker: Soft Allarum.
sp.p: Hark, the fight renews, one hour more makes a full conquest, and I'll never give o'er till it be finished.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: But that no fame or credit can be got to conquer age,
I'd scorn for to present another's prisoner.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.p: Aged as I am, had I a sword I'd scorn as much to be subdued by thee.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: That shall be tried. Here, take your arms again.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: Art thou in earnest then? Come on i'faith. How now?
What means this, wilt thou not fight with me?

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Yes sir, that I will, with you I'll fight,
But never fight against you. See the man
That thrice this day preserved you from your foe,
And the last time I bore you off from death,
I that man am now your champion, do not question why?
But rest assured, for you I'll live and die.

div.stage: Alarum, and the shepherds within crying, fly, fly, etc. enter Eusanius, and all the shepherds.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.p: What coward's that began this fearful cry? Is not the day likely to be our own? Have I not taken their King prisoner, seized his white flag, and by our general's hand sent him unto Pheander?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: But he's revolted, and has set him free,
And we have never a general to lead us.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.p: O villain, traitor, coward, were he my father I should call him so: fly from his colours. Courage, fellow swains, let us not blot the honour we have won. Want of a general, I'll supply that place, rather than lose so fair a victory.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: No, I'll be general.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and so you shall, and I'll be commander over you. We should be led like wildgeese then i'faith: wildgeese, nay woodcocks rather; for your wildgeese keep their wings, their front, their rear, and have a leader too.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Ay, ay, you are the man.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Follow then, come.

div.stage: A great alarum. Enter Radagon.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Sound a retreat, it is impossible to win the day,
sp.p: These shepherds fight like devils: I saw a man born on our lances points quite from the earth, yet when he came to ground he fought again, as if his strength had been invincible.
Hark how the proud foe with triumphant voice
Proclaims unto the world her victory.

div.stage: Enter 2 Sicilian lord.

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: Hark how Sicilia with triumphant voice
Proclaims unto the world his victory.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Sicilia?

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.p: Ay, Sicilia. Sophos, brother to the Thracian King, is with Alcade King of the Africans, come to assist you.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: Give 'em entertain with all the royal pomp our state can yield.

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: He shall have soldier's welcome, that's the best.

div.stage: Tromp. Flor. enter one way Scicillia and lords. Another, Alcade, Sophos, Lilla Guida, drums and colours.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.p: To give a welcome fitting to the state of Affrick's King, Sophos, and this fair dame, whose beauty all the western world admires, were to neglect a greater happiness; for by your aid fair victory sits crowned, pluming her golden wings upon our crest, let us not beat her back by detraction.

sp.speaker: Alcade.
sp.p: Royal sir, we come to fight, and not to feast; yet for this might we will repose ourselves, our troops are weary, and our beauteous child rests undisposed of; let her have a guard of demi Negros, called from either part, and let her lodgings be place next our own, that's all we do desire.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: Which we'll perform.

sp.speaker: Sophos.
sp.p: Let the retreat we heard at our approach, call back your powers, and early in the morn whenas the daring enemy comes on; thinking to prey upon a yielding foe.

sp.speaker: Tromp. Flor.
sp.l: Our forces shall confound 'em, Thrace shall know retreat. Sophos is here, come to perform his vow.

div.stage: Enter Pallemon wounded, Titterus, and clown:

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Upon 'em, upon 'em, upon 'em, they fly, they fly, they fly.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Ay, ay, they run away.

sp.speaker: Titter.
sp.p: I am glad they are retreated, had they stood, his lack of sense had been his loss of life, howe'er he scapes it yet, come now retire.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I'll have my love first.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: So ho, ho boys.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What noise is that? are you a fouler, sir?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I know what belongs to a retreat sir, I was the first man took flight, and lured off the rest as well as I could.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then y' are an engineer?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: An admirable fellow Pallemon, hold him in talk whilst I run for Cerena, and use my best persuasions to procure her gentle patience, his deep wounds to cure.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Come then grave Nestor to the council table, nay, you shall see that I can speak to you.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And you shall hear that I can answer you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You say you are a falconer?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Or a fowler, which you please.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: What think you, Nestor, if we limed our pikes, as you your twigs, and set 'em in the way just as the army flies? Do you not think they would hang fast by the wings?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Yes, if they do not leave their wings behind 'em,
And fly away with their legs.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: May they do so?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Faith I sir, 't has been the coward's fashion time out of mind.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Or father, shall's cast into the air a gorgeless falcon, that mounting the bleak region, till she spy my beauteous love Serena, then souse down, and snatch her from the army. Jove's bird the eagle, in her talons bore his darling Ganymede to his palace so. Speak Nestor, is it possible or no?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Very easy sir, if women be made of such light stuff, as they say they are; besides, no falcon but dares venture upon a ring-tale, and what's a woman else?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then as stern Pyrrhus did old Priam take, or stay,
As cruel Nero with his mother did,
I'll rip thy bowels out, then fling thee
Like a gorgeless falcon in the air;
But first I'll tie these bells unto thy legs,
That I may know which way to follow thee.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nay, and you begin to meddle with my legs,
I'll show you as fair a pair of heels,
As e'er you saw in your life.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Nay, fly me not, my fair Angelica.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Put up thy Elbow then, my mad Orlando.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Thy hand shall be the scabbard, there it is:
I yield me to thy mercy, Alexander;
Yet save my life, great Caesar.

div.stage: Enter Titterus and Serena.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: As we are Alexander, we will save thy life.
Come sit at Caesar's feet. So, so, now I'll
Deal well enough with you.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Prithee have more remorse, if not for love,
For love of life, help to redress his wounds;
remember 'tis for you he came thus hurt,
Take pity on his smart.

sp.speaker: Seren.
sp.p: Had I like power to restore his sense, as to recure his wounds, upon the earth I would leave no means unthought, unsought for, but I'd apply't for his recovery.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: This is the tyranny we men endure,
Women can make us mad, but none can cure.

sp.speaker: Seren.
sp.l: O may I prove the first, upon my knees,
If ever a poor virgin's prayers were heard,
Grant the fruition of my suit may prove
A saving health both to his life and love.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Nay, and you go about it with such willingness,
'Twill come to a good end sure:
The whilst you dress his wounds, I'll sit and sing,
And invocate the gods to pity him.
Fair Apollo, whose bright beams
Cheers all the world below:
The birds that sing, the plants that spring,
The herbs and flowers that grow.
O lend thy aid to a swain sore oppressed,
That his mind soon may find the delight that sense admits;
And by a maid let his harms be redressed,
That no pain do remain in his mind to offend his wits.

sp.speaker: Seren.
sp.l: His blood returns, rub his pulses o'er the fire,
His looks prescribe an alteration.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Would I could hear him speak a wise word once.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Either the earth, or else my head turns round.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Lass, my poor brother.

sp.speaker: Seren.
sp.l: Peace, disturb him not.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: And yet methinks I do not feel such pains as I was wont to endure. Ha, sure I should know! Speak, are not you my love?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: He knows her, ay, 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And you my brother?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: And what am I?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: A fool.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But you are no madman now? I'm sure. He that can distinguish a fool from a woman, is a wise man believe it.

sp.speaker: Seren.
sp.p:
Pallemon see, since it hath pleased the gods, in pity of
thy youth, to grant thy sense, Serena grants her love, and at thy feet craves pardon for her cruel injury.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: More welcome now then ever, my Serena.
Love that is often crossed, at length obtained,
Is sweeter far than pleasure easily gained.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: But what shall I do now? I'm gone in the common-law, and if a jury of women go upon me, I'm sure to be cast. I think I had best to appeal to the men first, and make them my arbitrators.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: O no, no, no, make your peace with the women first, whate'er you do; for if they take the matter in hand, your men are never able to stand long in a case against them.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Then first to you whom I have wronged so much,
And next, to all that's here.
Forgive me, o forgive me my cruel disdain,
Never poor lover endured such pain,
As I will in my skill, your praises to tell,
And never sing other, till death rings my knell.
Therefore no man hate a woman, for now you may prove
It lies in their powers to restore life and love.
Therefore no man hate a woman, for now you may prove
It lies in their power to restore life and love.

div.stage: A great alarum and excursions, then enter Eusanius and shepherds, with Alcade, Sophos, and white Moor, prisoners.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.p: The honour of thy overthrow, brave Moor, is due to great Pheander King of Thrace; but thy crowns ransom does belong to me.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.l: Take life and all, it is not worth the keeping,
Without addition of a victory.
To be a peasant's prisoner! Cursed fate!
Why should a King be so unfortunate?

sp.speaker: Sophos.
sp.p: Unhappy chance! Came I to Thrace for this, to lose both life and honour in the land that gave me life? and by a brother too? Black destiny!

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.p: Some post unto Pheander; and glad his ears with this our victory.

sp.speaker: Enter 1 Th. lord.
sp.p:
Why come ye on so slowly? renew the fight, our King is taken prisoner by that slave, that by his falling off lost
the last battle.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Pheander taken?

sp.speaker: Alcade
sp.p: That's some comfort yet, I hope Sicilia will not ransom him, till he consent unto our liberty.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: And if he should, he were unworthy to be termed a King.

sp.speaker: Eus
sp.l: Why then let's summon 'em unto a parley,
First offer to exchange our prisoners,

sp.speaker: A parley.
sp.l: And then begin the bloody fight again.

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: Summon a parley then.
sp.stage: Enter Scicillia, lords, with Pheander prisoner.
sp.p: Look here Sicilia, since by chance of war our Thracian King is taken prisoner, to ransom him we will deliver back into your hands the great Alcade, Sophos, and this white Moor.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Three prisoners for one, detain 'em still, I'll not be ransomed at so dear a rate.

sp.speaker: Alcade
sp.l: And if thou shouldst, I scorn it should be so;
For look what ransom Sicilia sets down,
I'll pay it trebly o'er to ransom us.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.p: We'll take no ransom, but will set you free by force of arms.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Bear back the prisoners, and renew the fight.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: Stay, darest thou that seemest so forward, hand to hand, in single opposition end this strife?

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: O were these Kings but pleased it should be so,
How soon would we decide this difference?

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: What says Alcade? if he be so content,
I'll gladly put my right upon his sword.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: The like will I upon my champion, whose unmatched valour has been well approved.

sp.speaker: Alcade.
sp.l: I like his fair aspect, and give consent.
Mayest thou prove happy in this enterprise.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: I'll lose my life, or gain your liberty.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: The like will I, or set Pheander free.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Then till the champions be in readiness, let the conditions be concluded on. Pallatio, draw the articles for us.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: And you for us, if we be overcome, Pheander is to have his liberty, and we depart this land, resigning back all interest due by his permission, and never seek revenge for our lost son: this as we are royal, we'll consent unto.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
If Thrace be overcome, he shall surrender all his dignity
into our hands, which Sophos shall enjoy which our fair daughter, paying Sicily a yearly tribute; and your soldiers pay since their abode in Thrace, shall be discharged from our exchequer.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: This I'll add besides, because by us Cicillia lost a for, whoever shall enjoy the crown of Thrace shall once a year, clad in his pilgrim's weeds, offer sacrifice unto the gods, and lay his crown down at Sicilia's feet.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: And Sophos vows to offer up his life,
A ransom for this beauteous African,
If we be vanquished by our enemy.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: There's Sicilia's hand.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.l: There Alcade.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: And mine?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: And Sophos joined in one.

sp.speaker: 1 Thr. lord.
sp.l: A happy end crown this contention.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Beseech your graces, since this difference is to be ended by a shepherd's hand, to let our Queen be set at liberty, to see the champion that must fight for her.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Go fetch her forth: and now I call to mind the oracle, that said a shepherd should restore my crown; sure one of these will prove that happy man.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: The trumpet sounds again, let's take our seats, and see who shall obtain the victory.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Nay altogether now, till the last stroke make a division.
sp.stage: Enter Ariadne brought in by shepherds.
sp.l: O the shepherd's Queen!

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.l: A lovely dame! sit by our daughter's side.

sp.speaker: Tuckets.
sp.p: The combatants will take encouragement from your fair eyes: hark, now they come.

div.stage: Enter Radagon brought in by the Cicilsian lords, Eusanius by the shepherds, with shields pictured with Neptune riding upon the waves.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Now boy, thrust home, 'tis for a lady.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Courage fellow swain.

sp.speaker: 1 lord,
sp.l: The champions are prepared, sound to the fight:

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: I for my King.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: I for my country's right fight.

sp.speaker: 2 lord.
sp.l: So, recover breath.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What means that strange device upon their shields? 'tis something sure concerns the oracle, God Neptune riding on the waves o'th sea, I'll question them to know the meaning on't.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.l: What means the King of Thrace?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: To ask a question ere they fight again.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.l: Then speak aloud, we'll have no whispering.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I prithee tell me, 'tis to thee I speak: what heinous wrongs hast thou received from us, or good from these, that thou alone shouldst prove the chiefest champion for our enemy?

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: So please these Kings vouchsafe me audience, I shall tell you.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Speak freely.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: In brief Pheander, I am nor subject unto him, nor you, more than the duty of a son allows, though this rude transmigration of my hair, bars me your knowledge, with the change of time, yet here behold the banished Radagon.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.l: My son?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: My husband?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Shame and my joy so struggle in my breast, I shall dissolve to air: o my dear child!

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: Can it be possible that we should live so long together, and not know each other?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: I knew Menalchus, but not Radagon.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: I Mariana, not my beauteous wife: but what's become of my Eusanius, had I my child again, my joy were full.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Alas I lost him fourteen years ago, keeping my flocks upon the plain of Thrace.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.p: This greater tide of joy overcomes the less, and will not suffer me as yet to mourn.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Pray speak those words again, where did you lose him? on the plains of Thrace?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: Indeed I did, just fourteen years ago.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: The time, the place, how habited, and then.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: In a small coat made of a panther's skin, a garland on his head, and in his hand a hook made of a cane.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: The very same, the time, the place, the habit, all things just as you describe to me; that child, I being banished from my native soil, found sporting in the plains, and that's the child I carried with me into Africa.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Was that the child you brought into the court? wha adverse fate had I to banish him?

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Far worser fate had I to lose my love.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: That child, so found so lost,
Brought up in Africa, and banished thence,
Should be myself.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Eusanius? 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: O my dear child.

sp.speaker: Eus.
sp.l: Are you my mother? This my father then?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Is this my warlike grandchild?

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.l: What wonder's this?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Now is the oracle confirmed at full.
Here is the wonder being wracked at sea,
Which Neptune from his waves cast up again.
These are the lions that did guide the lambs,
Living as shepherds, being princes born.
And these the seas, whose-equal valour neither ebbs nor tides,
But makes a stand, striving for victory;
Their shields proclaim as much, whose figure is
Neptune commanding of the rugged waves.
And this the happy shepherd from the plain,
Whose sight restores me all my joys again.

sp.speaker: Scicil.
sp.l: Radagon, thou shalt wear Scicillia's crown.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Pheander's too, which is too small a satisfaction for the great wrongs he hath sustained by us.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Do not impose more cares upon my head,
Until my joys be fully finished.
Good father keep your crown, and govern still,
And let me frolic with my beauteous bride:
And for Pheander's crown, let me entreat
My uncle Sophos, partner in our wars,
May, if he survive, be King of Thrace.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: With all my heart; and for these harmless shepherds,
Whose loves have been copartners in our wars, once every year
They shall be feasted in our royal palace,
And still this day be kept as holiday
In the remembrance of the shepherd's Queen.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: 'T would ask an age of time to explicate all our delights. Eusanius, take our child, with her our royal crown of Africa. Thy pardon Sophos, for we promised thee.

sp.speaker: Sophos.
sp.l: I willingly resign my interest, sir.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: One forty days we'll hold a festival
Within the court of Thrace before we part.
When was there such a wonder ever seen?
Forty years banished, and live still a Queen!

div.p: If any gentlemen please to repair to my house aforesaid, they may be furnished with all manner of English, or French histories, romances, or poetry; which are to be sold, or read for reasonable considerations.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
